intro: Brassica oleronensis, commonly known as cabbage, is a member of the Brassicaceae family and is characterized by its compact, leafy head. It is a biennial plant that typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, with thick, fleshy leaves that form a dense rosette. The plant produces yellow flowers in the shape of a cross, typical of the mustard family. Its edible parts include the leaves, stems, and flowering heads, which are used in various culinary preparations. Brassica oleronensis is cultivated worldwide for its nutritional value and versatility in cooking.
